Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Contextualized and Automated Usability Testing for Mobile Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to advance usability testing of mobile applications by integrating contextualized and automated techniques. Unlike the traditional desktop environment, mobile user experience is heavily inﬂuenced by user context such as physical location, transport mode, social surroundings, and task intention. The novelty of this project is a model-based usability testing approach that quantitatively integrates user context. The expected outcomes include: 1) a new framework of automated usability analysis to improve the effectiveness of diary studies by jointly modeling user cognition, application state, and user context; 2) a set of operationalized usability rules developed for mobile applications; and 3) a simulation-based development toolkit for automated usability inspection. This project addresses an emerging research theme and an urgent practical usability problem, and is expected to produce technology solutions as well as educational materials.

This project addresses a practical need of the fast-growing mobile application industry. The software artifacts will be made available to both research communities and industry practitioners through open source technology transfer, which can significantly reduce the cost of mobile usability testing. The proposed research will be integrated with three new course modules taught by PI. Women and minority students will be recruited to participate both research and education activities. All the course materials will be made available online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current practice of mobile application usability testing often employs lab-based testing environment with significant manual efforts by usability experts to analyze and identify interaction design problems. This approach often cannot reveal usability issues encountered in real world under different context. Our project addresses this limitation by providing a solution that can automatically collect detailed in-the-field interaction events and employ a model-based approach for usability analysis and visualization. Specifically, our mobile client SDK can unobtrusively collect all touch screen interactions (e.g. taps, swipes, scrolls, etc.), system events (e.g. network condition, device resource, and key presses), and contextual information (e.g. device motion, ambient light and noise). These data are uploaded to our analytics cloud that automatically aggregates multiple users’ data to construct a traffic flow model, based on which novel usability metrics are calculated and visualized. Furthermore, both supervised classification and unsupervised clustering algorithms are employed to identify user frustration moments and locate where the usability problems occurred. The effectiveness of this system has been validated through extensive user studies with both in-house and other popular mobile apps on the market.

In collaboration with Dartmouth College, this project graduated 3 PhD students and 1 MS student, 2 of them are female students. There are 6 other students contribute to the project through part-time participation or summer internships to assist user studies and system implementations. In addition, 2 journal papers and 7 conference papers were published with 2 more conference papers are currently under review. The research results are incorporated into the teaching materials of relevant human computing interaction courses. The technology has attracted industry interest and is supported by the university to seek technology transfer. The successful research outcomes to date improves the state-of-art of usability testing for mobile apps, which will ultimately lead to better user experience and productivity. In particular, the automated system can benefit small development shops to scale their usability evaluation without significant expense.
